Description: The past decade has seen tremendous growth in the number of approved cancer therapies in the U.S.  However, many individuals with cancer receive therapies for indications without FDA approval.  This may reflect use of newer drugs for non-approved indications; re-purposing of older drugs, including drugs originally developed for non-oncology indications; and drug treatment in supportive/palliative care, where few medication clinical trials (and consequentially few FDA-approved medication indications) are found.  To enhance quality of care and improve patient outcomes, it is critical to understand when and why off-label therapies are used.  This session will examine population- and hospital-level factors that may influence off-label use of cancer therapies; data resources that can help assess re-purposing of older medications for cancer care; and opportunities and challenges in off-label drugs for supportive/palliative care.
SearchResultBody: APS02. Impact of Off-Label Therapies in Cancer Care and Outcomes across Populations
Title: Impact of Off-Label Therapies in Cancer Care and Outcomes across Populations
